article.title: Canis_Minor
article.paragraph: Canis MinorIPAc-enˌkeɪnɨs_ˈmaɪnəris a smallconstellationin theCelestial spherenorthern celestial hemisphere. In the second century, it was included as anAsterism (astronomy)asterism, or pattern, of two stars inPtolemy's 48 constellations, and it is counted among theList of constellations88 modern constellations. Its name isLatinfor "lesser dog", in contrast toCanis Major, the "greater dog"; both figures are commonly represented as following the constellation ofOrion (constellation)Orionthe hunter.

Canis Minor contains only two stars brighter than the fourthapparent magnitudemagnitude,Procyon(Alpha Canis Minoris), with a magnitude of 0.34, andGomeisa(Beta Canis Minoris), with a magnitude of 2.9. The constellation's dimmer stars were noted byJohann Bayer, who named eight stars including Alpha and Beta, andJohn Flamsteed, who numbered fourteen. Procyon is the seventh-List of brightest starsbrightest starin the night sky, as well as one of theList of nearest starsclosest. A yellow-whitemain sequencestar, it has awhite dwarfBinary starcompanion. Gomeisa is a blue-white main sequence star.Luyten's Staris a ninth-magnitudered dwarfand theSolar System's next closest stellar neighbour in the constellation after Procyon. The fourth-magnitudeHD 66141, which has evolved into an orangegiant stargianttowards the end of itsstellar evolutionlife cycle, was discovered to have a planet in 2012. There are two faintdeep sky objectswithin the constellation's borders. The 11Canis-Minoridsare ameteor showerthat can be seen in early December.
article.heading: History and mythology
article.paragraph: File:Cmi.jpgthumbleftCanis Minor, as depicted byJohann Elert BodeJohann Bodein his 1801 work ''Uranographia''Though strongly associated with theClassical GreeceClassical Greekcelestial cartographyuranographictradition, Canis Minor originates from ancientMesopotamia. Procyon and Gomeisa were calledMASH.TAB.BAor "twins" in theThree Stars Eachtablets, dating to around 1100 BC. In the laterMUL.APIN, this name was also applied to the pairs ofPi3 OrionisPi3andPi4 OrionisPi4OrionisandZeta GeminorumZetaandXi Orionis. The meaning ofMASH.TAB.BAevolved as well, becoming the twin deitiesLulalandLatarak, who are on the opposite side of the sky fromPapsukal, the True Shepherd of Heaven inBabylonian mythology. Canis Minor was also given the nameDAR.LUGAL, which translates to "the star which stands behind it", in theMUL.APIN; the constellation represents arooster. This name may have also referred to the constellationLepus (constellation)Lepus.cite journalJohn H.Rogers1998Origins of the Ancient Constellations: I. The Mesopotamian traditionsJournal of the British Astronomical Association1089–281998JBAA..108....9RDAR.LUGALwas also denotedDAR.MUENandDAR.LUGAL.MUENin Babylonia. Canis Minor was then calledtarlugalluinAkkadian astronomy.cite journalAstral Magic in Babyloniai–xiii+1–150 [116]Transactions of the American Philosophical Society, New Series8541995ReinerErica1006642

Canis Minor was one of the original 48 constellations formulated byPtolemyin his second-centuryAlmagest, in which it was defined as a specific pattern (Asterism (astronomy)asterism) of stars; Ptolemy identified only two stars and hence no depiction was possible.TheAncient Greekscalled the constellation /Procyon, "coming before the dog", transliterated intoLatinasAntecanis,Praecanis, or variations thereof, by Cicero and others. Roman writers also appended the descriptorsparvus,minororminusculus("small" or "lesser", for its faintness),septentrionalis("northerly", for its position in relation to Canis Major),primus(rising "first") orsinister(rising to the "left") to its nameCanis.cite bookAllenRichard Hinckley19631899Star Names: Their Lore and MeaningcorrectedDover PublicationsMineola, New York978-0-486-21079-7383https://books.google.com/books?idInGreek mythology, Canis Minor was sometimes connected with theTeumessian foxTeumessian Fox, a beast turned into stone with its hunter,Laelaps (mythology)Laelaps, byZeus, who placed them in heaven as Canis Major (Laelaps) and Canis Minor (Teumessian Fox).Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3,192.cite bookhttps://books.google.com/books?idNature Guide Stars and Planets275DK PublishingPenguin2012978-1-4654-0353-7Eratosthenesaccompanied the Little Dog with Orion, whileGaius Julius HyginusHyginuslinked the constellation withMaera (hound)Maera, a dog owned byIcarius#Icarius of AthensIcarius of Athens.cite bookKlepeštaJosefRükl, AntonínConstellationsHamlynLondon, England19741969118–19978-0-600-00893-4On discovering the latter's death, the dog and Icarius' daughterErigone (daughter of Icarius)Erigonetook their lives and all three were placed in the skyErigone asVirgo (constellation)Virgoand Icarius asBotes.cite webhttp://www.ianridpath.com/startales/canisminor.htmRidpathIanCanis Minor26 May 2012Star TalesAs a reward for his faithfulness, the dog was placed along the "banks" of the Milky Way, which the ancients believed to be a heavenly river, where he would never suffer from thirst.Mark R. Chartrand III (1982) Skyguide: A Field Guide for Amateur Astronomers, p. 126 (ISBN 0-307-13667-1).

Theastronomy in medieval Islammedieval Arabic astronomersmaintained the depiction of Canis Minor (al-Kalb al-AsgharinArabic) as a dog; in hisBook of the Fixed Stars,Abd al-Rahman al-Sufiincluded a diagram of the constellation with a canine figure superimposed.cite journal179–197 [195–96]A Manuscript of "The Book of the Fixed Stars" by ʿAbd Ar-Raḥmān Aṣ-ṢūfīJoseph M.UptonMetropolitan Museum Studies42March 1933The Metropolitan Museum of Art152280010.2307/1522800cite journal1–26 [Plate 12]EmmyWelleszAn Early al-Ṣūfī Manuscript in the Bodleian Library in Oxford: A Study in Islamic Constellation ImagesArs Orientalis195934629096Freer Gallery of Art, The Smithsonian Institution and Department of the History of Art, University of MichiganThere was one slight difference between the Ptolemaic vision of Canis Minor and the Arabic; al-Sufi claimsMirzam, now assigned toOrion (constellation)Orion, as part of both Canis Minorthe collar of the dogand its modern home. The Arabic names for both Procyon and Gomeisa alluded to their proximity and resemblance to Sirius, though they were not direct translations of the Greek; Procyon was calledash-Shi'ra ash-Shamiya, the "Syrian Sirius" and Gomeisa was calledash-Shira al-Ghamisa, the Sirius with bleary eyes.Among theMerazigofTunisia, shepherds note six constellations that mark the passage of the dry, hot season. One of them, calledMerzem, includes the stars of Canis Minor and Canis Major and is the herald of two weeks of hot weather.cite journalA Review of African Ethno-Astronomy: With Particular Reference to Saharan Livestock-KeepersOxbyClaireLa Ricerca FolkloricaOctober 199957–58147976840

The ancient Egyptians thought of this constellation asAnubis, the jackal god.Chartrand, p. 126.File:Sidney Hall - Urania's Mirror - Monoceros, Canis Minor, and Atelier Typographique.jpgthumb400pxThe constellation Canis Minor can be seen alongsideMonocerosand the obsolete constellationAtelier Typographiquein this 1825 star chart from ''Urania's Mirror''.Alternative names have been proposed:Johann Bayerin the early 17th century termed the constellationFovea"The Pit", andMorus"SycamineTree". Seventeenth-century German poet and authorPhilipp von ZesenPhilippus Caesiuslinked it to the dog of Tobias from theBiblical apocryphaApocrypha.Richard A. Proctorgave the constellation the nameFelis"the Cat" in 1870 (contrasting with Canis Major, which he had abbreviated toCanis"the Dog"),explaining that he sought to shorten the constellation names to make them more manageable onStar chartcelestial charts.cite bookProctorRichard AnthonyRichard A. Proctor1870A Star Atlas for the Library, the School and the ObservatoryLongmans, GreenLondon, Englandhttps://books.google.com/books?id16–17Occasionally, Canis Minor is confused with Canis Major and given the nameCanis Orionis("Orion's Dog").cite book137Outer Space : Myths, Name Meanings, Calendars from the Emergence of History to the Present DayJobesGertrudeJobesJames1964Scarecrow PressNew York, New York882705
article.heading: In non-Western astronomy
article.paragraph: InChinese astronomy, the stars corresponding to Canis Minor lie in theVermilion Bird (Chinese constellation)The Vermilion Bird of the South(,Nn Fng Zh Qu). Procyon, Gomeisa and Eta Canis Minoris form anasterism (astronomy)asterismknown as Nnh, the Southern River.cite web陳冠中陳輝樺http://aeea.nmns.edu.tw/2006/0607/ap060716.htmlAEEA (Activities of Exhibition and Education in Astronomy)zh:天文教育資訊網16 July 2006zhWith its counterpart, the Northern River Beihe (Castor (star)CastorandPollux (star)Pollux), Nnh was also associated with a gate or sentry. Along withZeta CancriZetaand8 Cancri,6 Canis Minorisand11 Canis Minorisformed the asterismShuiwei, which literally means "water level". Combined with additional stars inGemini (constellation)Gemini, Shuiwei represented an official who managed floodwaters or a marker of the water level.Neighboring Korea recognized four stars in Canis Minor as part of a different constellation, "the position of the water". This constellation was located in the Red Bird, the southern portion of the sky.cite journalA Korean Star MapRufusW. KarlChaoCelia316–26Isis354Autumn 194433084310.1086/358723

Polynesian peoplesoften did not recognize Canis Minor as a constellation, but they saw Procyon as significant and often named it; in theTuamotu Archipelagoit was known asHiro, meaning "twist as a thread of coconut fiber", andKopu-nui-o-Hiro("great paunch of Hiro"), which was either a name for the modern figure of Canis Minor or an alternative name for Procyon. Other names includedVena(after agoddess), onMangaiaandPuanga-hori(falsePuanga, the name forRigel), inNew Zealand. In theSociety Islands, Procyon was calledAna-tahua-vahine-o-toa-te-manava, literally "Aster the priestess of brave heart", figuratively the "pillar for elocution".cite bookMakemsonMaud Worcester1941Yale University PressNew Haven, ConnecticutThe Morning Star Rises: An Account of Polynesian Astronomyharv199, 209, 247, 267, 280cite journalTahitian Astronomy: Birth of the Heavenly BodiesHenryTeuiraThe Journal of the Polynesian Society162101–04June 190720700813TheWardaman peopleof theNorthern Territoryin Australia gave Procyon and Gomeisa the namesMagumandGurumana, describing them as humans who were transformed intoEucalyptusgum treesin thedreamtime. Although their skin had turned to bark, they were able to speak with a human voice by rustling their leaves.cite bookHarneyBill YidumdumaCairns, Hugh C.Dark SparklersHugh C. CairnsMerimbula, New South Wales20042003Revised1420-9750908-0-1

TheAztec calendarwas related toAztec astronomytheir cosmology. The stars of Canis Minor were incorporated along with some stars of Orion and Gemini into an asterism associated with the day called "Water".cite journalCalendar Animals and DeitiesKelleyDavid H.317–337 [333]Southwestern Journal of Anthropology163Autumn 19603629035
article.heading: Characteristics
article.paragraph: Lying directly south ofGemini (constellation)Gemini'sbright starsCastor (star)CastorandPollux (star)Pollux,cite bookNewellW.J.The Australian SkyJacaranda PressBrisbane, Queensland19701965530-7016-0037-37053675(invalid isbn)Canis Minor is a small constellation bordered byMonocerosto the south, Gemini to the north,Cancer (constellation)Cancerto the northeast, andHydra (constellation)Hydrato the east. It does not borderCanis Major; Monoceros is in between the two. Covering 183 square degrees, Canis Minor ranks seventy-first of the 88 constellations in size. It appears prominently in the southern sky during theNorthern Hemisphere's winter.cite bookRobert A.GarfinkleStar-hopping: Your Visa to Viewing the UniverseCambridge University PressCambridge, England199778–81978-0-521-59889-7The constellation boundaries, as set byEugne Joseph DelporteEugne Delportein 1930, are defined by a polygon of 14 sides. In theequatorial coordinate system, theright ascensioncoordinates of these borders lie betweenRA0706.4andRA0811.4, while thedeclinationcoordinates are betweendec13.22anddec−0.36.cite journalCanis Minor, Constellation BoundaryThe ConstellationsInternational Astronomical Unionhttp://www.iau.org/public/constellations/#cmi25 May 2012Most visible in the evening sky from January to March,cite bookEllyard, David; Tirion, Wil2008The Southern Sky Guide3rd19934https://books.google.com/books?idCambridge University PressPort Melbourne, Victoria978-0-521-71405-1Canis Minor is most prominent at 10 PM during mid-February.cite bookThe Monthly Sky GuideRidpathIanTirionWil7thCambridge University PressCambridge, England21–22978-0-521-68435-4It is then seen earlier in the evening until July, when it is only visible after sunset before setting itself, and rising in the morning sky before dawn.cite webhttp://rasnz.org.nz/Stars/Canis.htmCanis Major and Canis Minor, 2 Constellations for FebruaryRodmellPaulRoyal Astronomical Society of New Zealand17 January 2013The constellation's three-letter abbreviation, as adopted by theInternational Astronomical Unionin 1922, is "CMi".cite journalRussellHenry NorrisThe New International Symbols for the Constellations[[Popular Astronomy (US magazine)|Popular Astronomy]]30469–711922PA.....30..469R1922
article.heading: Notable features
Stars

template.arg: List of stars in Canis Minor

link.part: The constellation Canis Minor as it can be seen by the naked eye

article.paragraph: Canis Minor contains only two stars brighter than fourthapparent magnitudemagnitude. At magnitude 0.34,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentProcyon AB – Spectroscopic BinarySIMBAD8 January 2013Procyon, or Alpha Canis Minoris, is the seventh-List of brightest starsbrightest starin the night sky, as well as one of theList of nearest starsclosest. Its name means "before the dog" or "preceding the dog" in Greek, as it rises an hour before the "Dog Star",Sirius, ofCanis Major. It is abinary starsystem, consisting of a yellow-whitemain sequencestarcite bookIanRidpathWilTirion2001Stars and Planets GuidePrinceton University PressPrinceton, New Jersey978-0-691-08913-3100–01ofspectral typeF5 IV-V, named Procyon A, and a faintwhite dwarfcompanion of spectral type DA, named Procyon B. Procyon B, which orbits the more massive star every 41 years, is of magnitude 10.7.Procyon A is 1.4 times thesolar massSun's mass, while its smaller companion is 0.6 times as massive as the Sun.cite journalGatewoodGeorgeHanInwooAn Astrometric Study of ProcyonAstronomical Journal13121015–21200610.1086/4988942006AJ....131.1015GThe system isconvert11.4lypcoffonfromEarth, the shortest distance to a northern-hemisphere star of the first magnitude.cite bookThe Cambridge Encyclopedia of Stars63KalerJames B.Cambridge University Press2006Cambridge, England978-0-521-81803-2Gomeisa, or Beta Canis Minoris, with a magnitude of 2.89, is the second-brightest star in Canis Minor. Lyingconvert162lypcoffofffrom theSolar System, it is a blue-whitemain sequencestar ofspectral classB8 Ve.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewBet CMiAmerican Association of Variable Star ObserversInternational Variable Star Index13 January 20134 January 2010Although fainter to Earth observers, it is much brighter than Procyon, and is 250 times asLuminosity#Astronomyluminousand three times as massive as the Sun.Cite journalJimKalerStarsGomeisa (Beta Canis Minoris)University of Illinoishttp://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/gomeisa.html27 January 2012Although its variations are slight, Gomeisa is classified as ashell star(Gamma Cassiopeiae variable), with a maximum magnitude of 2.84 and a minimum magnitude of 2.92.It is surrounded by a disk of gas which it heats and causes to emit radiation.

Johann Bayerused the Greek letters Alpha to Eta to label the most prominent eight stars in the constellation, designating two stars as Delta (named Delta1and Delta2).sfnWagman200376–77John Flamsteednumbered fourteen stars, discerning a third star he named Delta3;sfnWagman200377his star 12 Canis Minoris was not found subsequently.sfnWagman2003369In Bayer's 1603 workUranometria, Procyon is located on the dog's belly, and Gomeisa on its neck.sfnWagman2003504Gamma Canis MinorisGamma,Epsilon Canis MinorisEpsilonandEta Canis Minorislie nearby,marking the dog's neck, crown and chest respectively.sfnWagman2003504Although it has an apparent magnitude of 4.34, Gamma Canis Minoris is an orangestellar classificationK-typegiant stargiantof spectral class K3-III C, which liesconvert318lypcoffoffaway.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentGamma Canis MinorisSIMBAD25 May 2012Its colour is obvious when seen through binoculars.cite bookKambičBojanViewing the Constellations with Binoculars: 250+ Wonderful Sky Objects to See and ExploreSpringerNew York, New York200932978-0-387-85354-3https://books.google.com/books?idIt is a multiple system, consisting of thespectroscopic binaryGamma A and three optical companions, Gamma B, magnitude 13; Gamma C, magnitude 12; and Gamma D, magnitude 10. The two components of Gamma A orbit each other every 389.2 days, with an eccentric orbit that takes their separation between 2.3 and 1.4astronomical units(AU).cite webhttp://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/gammacmi.htmlGamma Canis MinorisKalerJimStar of the Week29 January 201319 March 2010Epsilon Canis Minoris is a yellowbright giantof spectral class G6.5IIb of magnitude of 4.99.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentEpsilon Canis MinorisSIMBAD25 May 2012It liesconvert988-1196lypcoffofffrom Earth, with 13 times the diameter and 750 times the luminosity of the Sun.cite bookBagnallPhilip M.The Star Atlas Companion: What You Need to Know about the ConstellationsSpringerNew York, New York20121-4614-0830-X108–12https://books.google.com/books?idEta Canis Minoris is a giant of spectral class F0III of magnitude 5.24,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentEta Canis MinorisSIMBAD25 May 2012which has a yellowish hue when viewed through binoculars as well as a faint companion of magnitude 11.1.cite bookDavid Malin, David J. FrewHartung's Astronomical Objects for Southern Telescopes: A Handbook for Amateur ObserversCambridge University PressCambridge, England1995184978-0-521-55491-6https://books.google.com/books?idLocated 4arcsecondsfrom the primary, the companion star is actually around 440 AU from the main star and takes around 5000 years to orbit it.cite webhttp://stars.astro.illinois.edu/sow/etacmi.htmlEta and Delta-1 CMiKalerJimStarsUniversity of Illinois22 August 2012

Near Procyon, three stars share the nameDelta Canis Minoris.Delta1 Canis MinorisDelta1is a yellow-whitestellar classificationF-typegiant stargiantof magnitude 5.25 located aroundconvert790lypcoffofffrom Earth. About 360 times as luminous and 3.75 times as massive as the Sun, it is expanding and cooling as it ages, having spent much of its life as aB-type main-sequence starmain sequence starof spectrum B6V.Also known as 8 Canis Minoris,Delta2 Canis MinorisDelta2is anF-type main-sequence starof spectral type F2V and magnitude 5.59 which isconvert136lypcoffoffdistant.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident8 Canis MinorisSIMBAD13 January 2013The last of the trio,Delta3 Canis MinorisDelta3(also known as 9 Canis Minoris), is aA-type main-sequence starwhite main sequence starof spectral type A0Vnn and magnitude 5.83 which isconvert680lypcoffoffdistant.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident9 Canis MinorisSIMBAD13 January 2013These stars mark the paws of the Lesser Dog's left hind leg, while magnitude 5.13Zeta Canis MinorisZetamarks the right.sfnWagman2003504A blue-whitebright giantof spectral type B8II, Zeta lies aroundconvert623lypcoffoffaway from the Solar System.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentZeta Canis MinorisSIMBAD6 September 2012

Lying approximately 264 light-years (81 parsecs) away with an apparent magnitude of 4.39,cite webhttp://exoplanet.eu/catalog/hd_66141_b/Planet HD 66141 bZolotukhinIvan2012Exoplanet.euParis Observatory21 December 2012HD 66141is 6.8 billion years old and hasStellar evolution#Mid-sized starsevolvedinto an orange giant of spectral type K2III with a diameter around 22 times that of the Sun, and weighing 1.1 solar masses. It is 174 times as luminous as the Sun, with anabsolute magnitudeof 0.15.Cite journalDetection of an Exoplanet Around the Evolved K Giant HD 661411211.20542012Astronomy & Astrophysics54810.1051/0004-6361/201118014Lee, B.-C.; Mkrtichian, D. E.; Han, I.; Park, M.-G.; Kim, K.-M.A1182012A&A...548A.118LHD 66141 was mistakenly named 13 Puppis, as its celestial coordinates were recorded incorrectly when catalogued and hence mistakenly thought to be in the constellation ofPuppis; Bode gave it the name Lambda Canis Minoris, which is now obsolete.sfnWagman2003460The orange giant is orbited by a planet,HD 66141b, which was detected in 2012 by measuring the star'sradial velocity. The planet has a mass around 6 times that ofJupiterand aorbital periodperiodof 480 days.

Ared giantof spectral type M4III,BC Canis Minorislies aroundconvert500lypcoffoffdistant from the Solar System.cite journalLong-term Photometry and Periods for 261 Nearby Pulsating M GiantsTaburV.BeddingT. R.2009[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]40041945–6110.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15588.xKissL. L.MoonT. T.SzeidlB.KjeldsenH.0908.32282009MNRAS.400.1945TIt is asemiregular variable starthat varies between a maximum magnitude of 6.14 and minimum magnitude of 6.42.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewBC CMiAmerican Association of Variable Star ObserversInternational Variable Star Index13 January 201325 August 2009Periods of 27.7, 143.3 and 208.3 days have been recorded in its pulsations.AZ Canis MinorisAZ,AD Canis MinorisADandBI Canis MinorisareDelta Scuti variablesshort period (six hours at most) pulsating stars that have been used asCosmic distance ladder#Standard candlesstandard candlesand as subjects to studyastroseismology.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsots_delsctDelta Scuti and the Delta Scuti VariablesTempletonMatthew16 July 2010Variable Star of the SeasonAAVSO (American Association of Variable Star Observers)3 November 2012AZ is of spectral type F0III,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentV* AZ Canis Minoris – Variable of Delta Scuti typeSIMBAD1 October 2012and ranges between magnitudes 6.44 and 6.51 over a period of 2.3 hours.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewAZ CMiAAVSOInternational Variable Star Index14 January 20134 January 2010AD has a spectral type of F2III,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentV* AD Canis Minoris – Variable of Delta Scuti typeSIMBAD1 October 2012and has a maximum magnitude of 9.21 and minimum of 9.51, with a period of approximately 2.95 hours.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewAD Canis MinorisAAVSOInternational Variable Star Index17 January 20134 January 2010BI is of spectral type F2 with an apparent magnitude varying around 9.19cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentV* BI Canis Minoris – Variable of Delta Scuti typeSIMBAD1 October 2012and a period of approximately 2.91 hours.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewBI Canis MinorisAAVSOInternational Variable Star Index17 January 20132 February 2011

At least three red giants areMira variablesin Canis Minor.S Canis Minoris, of spectral type M7e,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentS Canis MinorisSIMBAD27 August 2012is the brightest, ranging from magnitude 6.6 to 13.2 over a period of 332.94 days.cite webhttp://www.aavso.org/vsx/index.php?viewS CMiAAVSOInternational Variable Star Index14 January 20134 January 2010V Canis Minorisranges from magnitude 7.4 to 15.1 over a period of 366.1 days. Similar in magnitude isR Canis Minoris, which has a maximum of 7.3, but a significantly brighter minimum of 11.6. AnS-type star, it has a period of 337.8 days.cite bookPatrick Moore's Data Book of AstronomyMoorePatrickReesRobin396978-0-521-89935-2Cambridge University Press2011

YZ Canis Minorisis ared dwarfof spectral type M4.5V and magnitude 11.2,cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentV* YZ Canis Minoris – Variable of BY Draconis TypeSIMBAD1 October 2012roughly three times the size of Jupiter andconvert20lypcoffofffrom Earth. It is aflare star, emitting unpredictable outbursts of energy for mere minutes, which might be much more powerful analogues ofsolar flares.cite journalFirst Flares on a Distant StarNew Scientist4 February 1982305https://books.google.com/books?idInformationReed BusinessLuyten's Star(GJ 273) is a red dwarf star of spectral type M3.5V and close neighbour of the Solar System. Its visual magnitude of 9.9 renders it too faint to be seen with the naked eye,cite webThe One Hundred Nearest Stars1 January 2012Georgia State University Astronomyhttp://www.chara.gsu.edu/RECONS/TOP100.posted.htm1 October 2012Atlanta, Georgiaeven though it is onlyconvert12.39lypcoffonaway.cite webhttp://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?IdentLHS 33 – High Proper-motion StarSIMBAD5 October 2012Fainter still isPSS 544-7, an eighteenth-magnitude red dwarf around 20 percent the mass of the Sun, locatedconvert685lypcoffofffrom Earth. First noticed in 1991, it is thought to be a cannonball star, shot out of a star cluster and now moving rapidly through space directly away from theDisc (galaxy)galactic disc.cite journalde La Fuente Marcos, R.; de La Fuente Marcos, C.A Cannonball Star Candidate in Canis MinorNew Astronomy107551–5910.1016/j.newast.2005.04.0012005R.De La Fuente MarcosC.2005NewA...10..551D

TheWZ Sagittae-typedwarf novaDY CMi(also known asVSX J074727.6+065050) flared up to magnitude 11.4 over January and February 2008 before dropping eight magnitudes to around 19.5 over approximately 80 days. It is a remote binary star system where awhite dwarfand low mass star orbit each other close enough for the former star to draw material off the latter and form anaccretion disc. This material builds up until it erupts dramatically.cite journalShears, Jeremy; Brady, Steve; Bolt, Greg; Campbell, Tut; Collins, Donald F.; Cook, Lewis M.; Crawford, Timothy R.; Koff, Robert; Krajci, Tom; McCormick, Jennie; Nelson, Peter; Patterson, Joseph; Ponthière, Pierre de; Potter, Mike; Rea, Robert; Roberts, George; Sabo, Richard; Staels, Bart; Vanmunster, Tonny2009VSX J074727.6+065050: A New WZ Sagittae Star in Canis MinorJournal of the British Astronomical Association1196340–46http://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/0905/0905.0061.pdf0905.00612009JBAA..119..340S
article.heading: Deep-sky objects
article.paragraph: TheMilky Waypasses through much of Canis Minor, yet it has fewdeep-sky objects.cite bookInglisMikeAstronomy of the Milky Way: Observer's Guide to the Southern SkySpringerNew York, New York2004201-85233-742-7https://books.google.com/books?idWilliam Herschelrecorded four objects in his 1786 workCatalogue of Nebulae and Clusters of Stars, including two he mistakenly believed were star clusters.cite bookBrattonMarkThe Complete Guide to the Herschel Objects: Sir William Herschel's Star Clusters, Nebulae and GalaxiesCambridge University PressCambridge, England2011134978-0-521-76892-4https://books.google.com/books?idNGC 2459is a group of five thirteenth- and fourteenth-magnitude stars that appear to lie close together in the sky but are not related.cite webhttp://cseligman.com/text/atlas/ngc24a.htm#2459NGC Objects: NGC 2450 – 2499Celestial AtlasSeligman, Courtney25 May 2012A similar situation has occurred withNGC 2394, also in Canis Minor.cite webhttp://cseligman.com/text/atlas/ngc23a.htm#2394NGC Objects: NGC 2350 – 2399Celestial AtlasSeligman, Courtney25 May 2012This is a collection of fifteen unrelated stars of ninth-magnitude and fainter.

Herschel also observed three faint galaxies, two of which are interacting with each other.NGC 2508is alenticular galaxyof thirteenth-magnitude, estimated at 205 million light-years (63 million parsecs) distance with a diameter of 80 thousand light-years (25 thousand parsecs).cite webhttp://cseligman.com/text/atlas/ngc25.htm#2508NGC Objects: NGC 2500 – 2549Celestial AtlasSeligman, Courtney25 May 2012Named as a single object by Herschel,NGC 2402is actually a pair of near-adjacent galaxies that appear to be interacting with each other. Only of fourteenth- and fifteenth-magnitudes respectively, the elliptical and spiral galaxy are thought to be approximately 245 million light-years distant, and each measure 55,000 light-years in diameter.cite webhttp://cseligman.com/text/atlas/ngc24.htm#2402NGC Objects: NGC 2400 – 2449Celestial AtlasSeligman, Courtney25 May 2012
article.heading: Canis Minorids
article.paragraph: The 11Canis-Minorids, also called the Beta Canis Minorids,cite bookJenniskensPeterMeteor Showers and Their Parent Comets200, 769Cambridge University Press2006978-0-521-85349-1are ameteor showerthat arise near the fifth-magnitude star11 Canis Minorisand were discovered in 1964 by Keith Hindley, who investigated theirtrajectoryand proposed a common origin with the cometD/1917 F1Mellish.Cite journalHindleyK. B.HouldenM. A.10.1038/2251232a0The 11 Canis Minorids—A New Meteor Stream Probably Associated with Comet Mellish 1917 INature22552391232–331970160570041970Natur.225.1232HHowever, this conclusion has been refuted subsequently as the number of orbits analysed was low and their trajectories too disparate to confirm a link.cite journalMeteor Showers of Comet C/1917 F1 MellishP.VerešL.KornošJ.Tóth28 October 2010Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society1010.57332011MNRAS.412..511V10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17923.x412511–521They last from 4 to 15 December, peaking over 10 and 11 December.cite bookLevyDavid H.David Levy's Guide to Observing Meteor ShowersCambridge University PressCambridge, England2007122978-0-521-69691-3https://books.google.com/books?id
